channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: UK to welcome 20,000 Afghans amid Taliban takeover
item.description: Some 5,000 refugees will be eligible under a new scheme in the first year, on top of 5,000 Afghan staff.

item.title: Afghan women to have rights within Islamic law, Taliban say
item.description: The militant group, which has taken control of Afghanistan, is pressed on fears over women's freedoms.

item.title: Covid-vaccine scientists begin plague-jab trial
item.description: The first volunteers have received a dose of the vaccine, made using the same technology as the Covid jab.

item.title: 'NHS abandoned me after I tried to kill myself'
item.description: Mental health referrals across the UK have hit their highest point for two years.

item.title: Trendy shoffices and pizza ovens raised lockdown fire risks
item.description: Insurer Zurich says residential outbuilding fires rose by 16% last year compared with 2019.

item.title: Nando's shuts restaurants as it runs short of supplies
item.description: The chain says it will lend some of its own staff to its suppliers, to help tackle delays to deliveries.

item.title: Aspirin may help treat aggressive breast cancer
item.description: Doctors hope it could boost the anti-cancer power of other drugs to fight hard-to-treat tumours.

item.title: Trials of shared banking hubs to be extended
item.description: The two trial projects allow different banks to operate from the same premises after branches closed.

item.title: Outrage at chronic fatigue syndrome advice update pause
item.description: NICE decided to pause the final update to its advice just hours before planned publication.

item.title: Colleges need extra Â£570m due to rise in students - think tank
item.description: The IFS says England's colleges and sixth forms need extra funds to keep pace with student numbers.

item.title: Home Depot 'discriminated against BLM supporter'
item.description: The US DIY chain tried to stop a worker from raising issues of racial harassment with managers, a watchdog claims.

item.title: Greater Manchester Police chief scraps 'tosh' Citizens' Contract
item.description: Stephen Watson says a scheme defending squeezed police resources was "patronising nonsense".

item.title: Ex-marine: I'm not leaving Kabul without my animal rescue staff
item.description: Founder of an animal sanctuary Pen Farthing urges ministers to get 71 people to safety in the UK.

item.title: Afghanistan: What's the impact of Taliban's return on international order?
item.description: What is the diplomatic fallout and how allies and rivals are looking at the US following the Taliban takeover?

item.title: Afghanistan: Mysterious Taliban spokesman finally shows his face
item.description: The spokesman has appeared in public for the first time. But is there more than one Zabihullah Mujahid?

item.title: Afghanistan: Female Kabul resident fears for future under Taliban
item.description: A woman shares her story of the day the Taliban arrived - and why she has lost all hope.

item.title: Inside a Kabul hotel - Taliban guards, no women
item.description: The BBC's Malik Mudassir says Taliban fighters are now providing security at his hotel in central Kabul.

item.title: Taliban: 'We will not allow the soil of Afghanistan to be used against anyone'
item.description: The Taliban have held their first news conference since taking control of Afghanistan.

item.title: Afghanistan: Striking image captures Kabul exodus
item.description: A photo appears to show hundreds of Afghans packed on a US military plane as they flee the Taliban.

item.title: The Papers: UK's refugee plan 'big-hearted', or 'not enough'
item.description: Many of the papers focus on the UK's plan to resettle 20,000 Afghan refugees as part of a new scheme.

item.title: Covid: 'I'm pregnant, should I have the vaccine?'
item.description: Many pregnant women have declined the Covid jab, but what's best for the baby?

item.title: 'I make art out of discarded face masks'
item.description: Thomas Yates posts artwork he's created out of used face masks on social media.

item.title: How technology in the air battles fires on the ground
item.description: Planes equipped with infrared scanners are helping authorities take on historic wildfires in the US.

item.title: Astronomers see galaxies in ultra-high definition
item.description: Researchers capture some of the most detailed images ever seen of galaxies in deep space.

item.title: Art: Paintings by Sir Kyffin Williams sell for Â£39,000
item.description: The artworks, by one of Wales' most renowned artists, are described as "a truly wonderful find".

item.title: California man sues after being startled by dumpster-diving bear
item.description: A dumpster-diving bear allegedly "startled" the man and caused him to fall and hurt himself.

item.title: Afghanistan: The 'pure devastation and guilt' of British-Afghans
item.description: We chat to young people in the UK who have family in Afghanistan, as the Taliban take control.

item.title: The little-known human stories behind emoji designs
item.description: The surprising story of how some tiny characters ended up on billions of smartphone keyboards.

item.title: Nubya Garcia: The British sax star who is jazzing up the BBC Proms
item.description: Saxophonist Nubya Garcia on playing Royal Albert Hall, the Mercury Prize and "natural vibrations".

item.title: Never mind going electric, where will we park?
item.description: UK roads are already jam-packed and that looks set to get worse as more people snap up EVs.

item.title: Afghanistan: 'My family is stuck and there is nothing I can do'
item.description: Afghans who have settled in the UK tell BBC News of their fears for loved ones back home.

item.title: Love and money: 'I borrowed from a friend, it went wrong'
item.description: After sleeping on the night bus with her daughter, Jo was forced to borrow money.

item.title: Afghanistan: Cardiff artist's sadness at Taliban takeover
item.description: Dan Peterson spent a month on the front line, drawing images of British soldiers and Afghan people.

item.title: Peter Karlsson: The painful verdict on Swedish ice hockey player's 1995 killing
item.description: Peter Karlsson was stabbed to death in the street. His killer said he was protecting himself - via the so-called 'gay panic' defence.

item.title: Livingstone powers Phoenix into men's Hundred final with brilliant 92 off 40 balls
item.description: Liam Livingstone's devastating hitting powers Birmingham Phoenix straight into the men's Hundred final with a crushing eight-wicket win over Northern Superchargers.

item.title: Carvalho shines as Championship leaders Fulham beat Millwall
item.description: Teenager Fabio Carvalho sets up one goal and scores the other as Fulham beat Millwall in the Championship.

item.title: 'Just talk' - Ronaldo criticises transfer rumours
item.description: Juventus striker Cristiano Ronaldo responds to rumours of a move away from the Italian club.

item.title: Konta knocked out in first round of Cincinnati Open
item.description: British number one Johanna Konta loses in the first round of the Cincinnati Open to Karolina Muchova.

item.title: 'I feel like a player again' - Wolves' Jimenez on his return after fractured skull
item.description: Wolves striker Raul Jimenez talks about his return to action following his skull fracture last season.

item.title: Hendry clinches first main-draw win since professional comeback
item.description: Stephen Hendry claims his first main-draw win since his return to the professional tour with a 3-2 victory over Chris Wakelin at the British Open.

item.title: Clucas taunts Swansea fans as Stoke go second with win
item.description: Stoke City's promising start to the season continues as they claim an impressive 3-1 victory at Swansea City.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Covid passport: How to prove your vaccine status with the NHS Covid Pass
item.description: Fully vaccinated adults will be able to avoid self-isolation after contact with someone with Covid.

item.title: Covid: What will school be like in the new term?
item.description: Pupils across the UK are preparing to return to school after the summer holidays.

item.title: Covid: When will teenagers get the jab and do I need a booster?
item.description: More teenagers will be able to receive the Covid vaccine, and a third jab will soon be available for the most vulnerable.

item.title: Covid rules: What's changing in Wales, Scotland, England and Northern Ireland?
item.description: Lockdown rules are changing across the UK, but some restrictions remain in place.

item.title: Covid: Do I have to self-isolate if I'm fully vaccinated?
item.description: Self-isolation rules have now been relaxed across the UK.

item.title: UK holidays: What are the rules?
item.description: Going abroad is not straightforward, so many people are opting to stay in the UK for their holidays.

item.title: 'How I found out my dad was a best-selling sex writer'
item.description: Sara Faith Alterman was always close to her father. Then she learned he was concealing a secret.

item.title: Plymouth shooting: Inside the dark world of 'incels'
item.description: Who are the angry young men who describe themselves as "involuntarily celibate"?

item.title: Wildfires: How Portuguese club Tondela drove through the flames
item.description: In Tondela, the bond between club and fans was at its strongest during the night in October 2017 when nobody slept.

item.title: Malta: The teenagers pulled from the sea and accused of terrorism
item.description: How three teenagers rescued from the Mediterranean Sea ended up in Malta accused of terrorism.
